title: The Chicago R User Group (CRUG): Rebooting...Live at the Haymarket Pub, Lightning Talks & Open Mic! üéâ üçª üéâ üç∑, United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join us in rebooting the Chicago R User Group with an evening of lightning talks and an open mic, live and in person!

**Doors open at 5:00, talks begin at 5:30!**

The pandemic kept many of us inside, writing copious amounts of new code for our hobbies & jobs. In the spirit of Open Source we welcome you, Chicagoland R users, to attend and consider contributing a short talk on the novel work you're proud of. As always, slides including simple code that can be displayed in a readable way is encouraged. Register here to present and/or just Bring Your Own Slide Deck! (https://forms.gle/oE7pXjkUzKyXuvQH9)

Open Mic: impromptu 5-10 minute talk on any R topic, on a FIFO basis. Scheduled Lightning Talks as follows, ordered by submission time:

Jeff Ryan (https://www.linkedin.com/in/jeffreyaryan/) on his mmap package: A tasty introduction to the power of memory mapping infinite data, with examples from astronomy and finance.

Rob Creel (https://www.linkedin.com/in/robcreel/) on Data Tidying Horror Stories: A quick exposition of lessons learned in wrangling data from varied sources.

Anh Tran (https://www.linkedin.com/in/anh-n-tran/) on Data Analysis for a local non-profit addressing the mental health treatment of incarcerated individuals.

Arafath Hossain (https://www.linkedin.com/in/arafath-hossain/) on using R to augment the ETL process.

Joseph Retzer (https://www.linkedin.com/in/josephretzer/) on Visualizing Non-Hierarchical Cluster Allocation Using Alluvial Diagrams in R.

Eugene Kravchenko (https://www.linkedin.com/in/eugenekravchenko/) on using R for to reproduce momentum investing methods decribed in Meb Faber's Tactical Asset Allocation, in the era of COVID-19.

Troy Hernandez, CRUG organizer (https://www.linkedin.com/in/troy-hernandez/): Prodromal Labor or Early Labor? Predicting Active Labor with a Linear Model (n=1)

** We are monitoring daily infection counts (currently falling) and will adjust the parameters of this event based on guidance from the City of Chicago and local experts in the field **

As vaccination rates continue to increase, Governor Pritzker has issued guidelines for all Illinois Businesses to reopen on June 11th! (https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=23399)
In step with the Governor, Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot has moved up the city's time table to match the state of Illinois, and will also fully reopen on June 11th! (https://www.reuters.com/world/us/chicago-reopen-fully-june-11-mayor-says-2021-06-04/)

Given our commitment to gathering safely, we are incentivizing vaccination of all in attendance by giving you FREE beverage tickets if you can display proof of receiving a COVID-19 vaccine. So bring your vaccine card and enjoy a beverage! üç∑üçª üç∑üçª

But wait...there's more! You may also receive a free plastic sleeve to protect your vaccine card. However, in the spirit of Reduce, Reuse, Recycle ‚ôª (hat tip, Troy Hernandez) you should reuse one of the many lanyards you've acquired from the conference circuit if possible.

If you aren't vaccinated, you still have time as doses are becoming widely available! Please visit the Illinois Department of Health COVID-19 Vaccine FAQ page for more details. (https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/vaccine-faq)

As always, please reach out to us with any questions or concerns. We look forward to seeing you live and in person at the Haymarket Pub & Brewery soon!

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjast√≥w R): Why R? Webinar 046 - Genomics @ Cloud with R  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe

description:
STREAM - https://youtu.be/3RkBEva4xRk
YouTube Channel - https://www.youtube.com/WhyRFoundationVideos

DESCRIPTION OF THE TALK

R and R-Bioconductor libraries are the popular tools in the genomics space,enabling researchers, clinicians and pharma to harness the power of -omic data,enabled through the entire portfolio of bioinformatics/biostatistics methods. Thissession will provide a foundational overview of genomics and introduce cloudenvironment‚Äôs rapidly growing portfolio of products and services for genomics dataanalysis with R. Talk will provide a glimpse into how cloud technologies are beingleveraged by different research partners to further their research and developmentactivities in advancing precision medicine, healthcare and beyond. Attendees will beintroduced to rapidly growing opportunities within genomics & healthcare in thecloud, understand R and R-Bioconductor‚Äôs best practices in genomics and beprovided resources to additional information about genomics opportunities,Genomics Data Science approaches and developments in healthcare.

BIOGRAPHY

Erdal Cosgun, Ph.D, ÔÅ°

Erdal Cosgun graduated from the Department of Statistics, Faculty of Science atHacettepe University in 2007. He worked in the Sectionon Statistical Genetics, Department of Biostatistics at the University of Alabama inBirmingham for 6 months in 2009. He received a 3-month bioinformatics training atthe R&D Campus at Pfizer Inc. and received a full scholarship from the company in2011. After finishing his Ph.D., he worked as an Asst. Prof. at Acƒ±badem University,Faculty of Medicine, Department of Biostatistics and Medical Informatics as Head ofthe Department. He has published over 40 original scientific papers and severalpresentations at conferences, particularly focused on statistical genetics andgenomics data science. He joined Microsoft as a Global Black Belt-TSP on AdvancedAnalytics in 2015. He was responsible for Machine Learning operations across theMEA region. He has been working at Microsoft Genomics since December 2016 as aSenior Data and Applied Scientist. He is also an ‚ÄòAssociate Professor of Biostatistics‚Äôaffiliated with Council of Higher Education in Turkey and Biostatistics editor of theTurkish Journal of Biochemistry (SCI).

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): May useR: Writing R code that maximizes our abilities to work collaboratively  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Writing R code that maximizes our abilities to work collaboratively
Presented by Ezra Tucker

Abstract:
How best to work with other data scientists in a team to organize and structure code? S4 classes in R give structure to your data and help you organize your methods. They also help signal to your team members proper use of the data structures you define and what methods are available, in essence, how to use your code properly, and also, how to add to it or modify it later on.

In this talk, we will empower ourselves by reminding ourselves that data scientists are a particular class of programmers (distinct from those who create PC/console games, those who create mobile apps, those who create websites, etc) but programmers all the same. Then we will briefly discuss the benefits of code encapsulation, especially with respect to packages and S4 classes while touching briefly on other OOP systems in R. We will discuss when and how to implement them, and how to structure your code base in a clean, effective, and consistent manner so that it's clear and easy to understand for your teammates and to yourself.

Speaker:
Ezra Tucker is the Director of Data Science at Energetic Insurance

Energetic Insurance is a Managing General Underwriter (MGU) with a novel, data-driven approach to develop new risk management products to unlock exponential growth in the renewable energy industry

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Leveraging Open Source in the Enterprise  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register Here: https://bit.ly/3uEDn7r

Travis Oliphant, CEO of OpenTeams and founder of Anaconda, joins Coiled to discuss the adoption of Python in the enterprise, how Open Source is such a productive modern development for businesses, and roadmaps for how the Enterprise can leverage Open Source to deliver business value.

Python is the de facto language for machine learning and AI, and is used across many verticals, including healthcare, finance, retail, and space exploration! What are the key features of Python and its community that made this happen? What gaps remain to even more robust adoption and usage in the Enterprise?

Join us to dive into the wonderful world of unlocking business value with Open Source Software!

After attending, you‚Äôll know:

- How Python and PyData (NumPy, pandas, scikit-learn, and many more!) got started;
- What are key reasons AI and ML practitioners use Python;
- What challenges had to be overcome to get Python adopted in the Enterprise;
- What challenges remain for Python adoption in organizations;
- What companies and service providers are helping the enterprise get more value faster out of their data.

Register Here: https://bit.ly/3uEDn7r

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] TigerGraph Cloud ‚Äì How to Run TigerGraph on AWS, Azure and GCP  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register Here: https://info.datascience.salon/introduction-to-tigergraph-cloud-how-to-run-tigergraph-on-aws-azure-and-gcp

TigerGraph Cloud, a cloud-agnostic database-as-a-service offering, enables users to leverage graph analytics on AWS, Azure, and GCP. TigerGraph Cloud not only fully manages clusters, but also provides a use case library via starter kits, which greatly reduces customers‚Äô time to business value and decreases the learning curve to specific graph database use cases such as fraud detection, recommendation, customer 360, AI, and in-database machine learning.

Come learn and ask questions from our TigerGraph Cloud Product Team and watch an end-to-end overview of TigerGraph Cloud with a short demonstration that showcases starter kits and other unique functionality.

Register Here: https://info.datascience.salon/introduction-to-tigergraph-cloud-how-to-run-tigergraph-on-aws-azure-and-gcp

title: Montreal R User Group: Speed Optimization & Benchmarks in Spark NLP 3: Making the Most of Hardware  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register: https://events.johnsnowlabs.com/speed-optimization-benchmarks-in-spark-nlp-3-making-the-most-of-modern-hardware

Spark NLP is the most widely used NLP library in the enterprise, thanks to implementing production-grade, trainable, and scalable versions of state-of-the-art deep learning & transfer learning NLP research. It is also Open Source with a permissive Apache 2.0 license that officially supports Python, Java, and Scala languages backed by a highly active community and JSL members.

Spark NLP library implements core NLP algorithms including lemmatization, part of speech tagging, dependency parsing, named entity recognition, spell checking, multi-class and multi-label text classification, sentiment analysis, emotion detection, unsupervised keyword extraction, and state-of-the-art Transformers such as BERT, ELECTRA, ELMO, ALBERT, XLNet, and Universal Sentence Encoder.

The latest release of Spark NLP 3.0 comes with over 1100+ pretrained models, pipelines, and Transformers in 190+ different languages. It also delivers massive speeds up on both CPU & GPU devices while extending support for the latest computing platforms such as new Databricks runtimes and EMR versions.

The talk will focus on how to scale Apache Spark / PySpark applications in YARN clusters, use GPU in Databricks new Apache Spark 3.x runtimes, and manage large-scale datasets in resource-demanding NLP applications efficiently. We will share benchmarks, tips & tricks, and lessons learned when scaling Spark NLP.

Register: https://events.johnsnowlabs.com/speed-optimization-benchmarks-in-spark-nlp-3-making-the-most-of-modern-hardware

title: Winnipeg R User Group: [Tunis R User Group] Introduction to Proteomics Using R  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
In support of the Global R User Group efforts to promote online events around the world featuring the R programming language, the Winnipeg R User Group is pleased to announce to our members this upcoming R user Group event put on by the Tunis R User Group.

Please RSVP and follow the attendance instructions at the original meet-up event page:

https://www.meetup.com/tunis-r-user-group/events/278773684/

______________________________________

We are happy to announce the start of our activities within Tunis R User Group (https://www.meetup.com/tunis-r-user-group/events/278773684/).

The first online workshop will serve as an introduction to proteomics using the programming language R. Join us to meet Dr. Laurent Gatto.

Dr. Laurent Gatto ( https://lgatto.github.io/about/) is an Associate Professor of Bioinformatics at the de Duve Institute, UCLouvain, in Belgium. His research group focuses on the development and application of statistical learning for the analysis and comprehension of large scale biological data. Since 2010, he has focused on the processing and analysis of mass spectrometry-based quantitative proteomics data in general, and spatial proteomics data in particular. The development and publication of scientific software is an integral part of his work, as reflected by his numerous contributions to the Bioconductor project. Laurent is an avid open research advocate, making his research outputs openly available. He is a Software Sustainability Institute fellow, a Data and Software Carpentry instructor and an ASAPbio ambassador.

Place: Zoom
Date/Time: Thursday, June 17, 2021 from 4PM to 7PM Tunisia time (GMT +1)

We recommend you to have a look at the convenient world clock website https://lnkd.in/gUAZxQM if you're struggling to find the right time according to your time zone.

Dr. Laurent will go through the first chapter of this material üëâ https://rformassspectrometry.github.io/docs/

In order to attend the meetup, please fill out this form üëâ https://tinyurl.com/taeuyum3

We will send you the Zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Cleveland R User Group: Frans van Dunn√©: Automating business processes with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
When we make an inventory of opportunities to add value to organizations with data, often there is low hanging fruit that does not require much investment in actual data analysis, but can be solved by automating data aspects of business processes. In fact there is a whole industry around this called robotic process automation (RPA). But where RPA offers a low-code approach to setting up automation tasks, it is easy to undervalue R for setting up these tasks with R code.

In this talk I would like to share some of the experiences we have had automating tasks with R. The tools we use range from great packages like fs to work with the filesystem on the R side. But there are also packages to make it easier to work with cron jobs on Linux (cronR) and the task scheduler on Windows (taskscheduleR).

When you combine this with other tools of the automation trade like httr to access API's or plumber to write API's there is practically no limit to what you can achieve using only R and readily available tools on linux and windows. I hope that the talk will inspire a lively discussion where we share experiences and ideas about automating processes with R.

Frans van Dunn√© (https://www.fransvandunne.com/) is Chief Data Officer at ixpantia (https://www.ixpantia.com/). He combines a diverse skill-set, that includes business analysis, data analysis and enterprise architecture, with more than 15 years of experience to help organizations respond to their data driven innovation needs quickly and effectively. Frans has a PhD in biology from the University of Amsterdam and has taught at universities in Europe and Latin America. As a consultant he has worked with companies around the world on diverse topics, including data driven innovation, applied statistics, statistical programming and machine learning.

Note: this talk will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel.

title: AalborgRUG: [R-Ladies Tunis] Introduce yourself online with blogdown & Hugo Ap√©ro  [Virtual] , Denmark, Europe
description:
From R-Ladies Tunis:

We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new workshop about Using blogdown & Hugo Ap√©ro to create your personal website.

Date/Time: Wednesday, May 26th, 2021 from 7 PM to 9 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Dr. Alison Hill

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Alison Hill :
Alison Hill is a data scientist, behavioral scientist, and an award-winning educator. Currently, Dr. Hill works to make data science communication easier and more delightful using RStudio‚Äôs open-source toolchain. Previously, Alison was an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Oregon Health & Science University. Her research focused on health-related applications of Natural Language Processing-based methods, and was funded by the National Institutes of Health, the Oregon Clinical and Translational Research Institute, and Autism Speaks. She has written numerous scientific publications on autism and neurodevelopmental disorders and has presented research at over 25 international conferences. Alison has also taught statistics and data science for over 10 years; most recently, she has led advanced workshops on data science communication and machine learning at rstudio::conf, R / Medicine, and R in Pharma. She is also an international keynote speaker (https://alison.rbind.io/talks), co-developer of the palmerpenguins (https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/), distill (https://rstudio.github.io/distill/), and blogdown (https://pkgs.rstudio.com/blogdown) R packages, and co-author of the book blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown (https://bookdown.org/yihui/blogdown/).

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:
‚ÄúYou should have a website!‚Äù You may have heard this one before, or even said it yourself. In this workshop, you‚Äôll learn how to build and customize a website from the comfort of the RStudio IDE with R Markdown. We'll use the blogdown package and the Hugo Ap√©ro theme to build and deploy a personal website. We‚Äôll cover basic website care and feeding like using R Markdown to create content, how to use GitHub for version control and Netlify for publishing, and how to use the latest upgrades to the blogdown R package to keep your site up and running.

title: AalborgRUG: Using Tidymodels, An Overview  [Virtual] , Denmark, Europe
description:
[bio]
Emil Hvitfeldt is a clinical data analyst at Teladoc health, adjunct professor at American University teaching statistical machine learning using tidymodels. a co-organizer of East Los Angeles R Users Group, and the author of [Supervised Machine Learning for Text Analysis in R](https://smltar.com/) with his coauthor Julia Silge. His interests include developing tools for natural language processing for machine learning models and the use of colors in data visualizations.

[Abstract]
The tidymodels framework is a collection of R packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. A large number of packages from preprocessing to evaluation come together to form a coherent framework for doing modeling: statistically, and machine learning-wise. This talk will walk through the landscape of packages and their individual place, helping you get a bird's eye view.

title: Portland R User Group: aggregate: meet, greet, learn, collaborate  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Please join us for the 41st R aggRegate meetup on Zoom! We welcome current or aspiring R users who have any level of experience with the R programming language.

Our goal is to exchange knowledge, learn new skills, help each other troubleshoot coding problems, and meet new fellow R users.

No topic is off limits, and you may attend even if you don‚Äôt feel that you have anything to share. Come learn with us!

When: Wednesday, May 26th, 2021 @ 6:30-8 PM

Where: Online: zoom info provided soon (provided after you join).

Details: Brittany Barker will provide a short demonstration of the purrr package in R. The purrr package enhances the functional programming aspect of R by providing different methods to work with functions and vectors. She will focus on how to use the map() function to replace loops and apply functions, which can streamline your workflow and simplify code.

Agenda:

‚Ä¢ Brittany's short demonstration of the purrr package

‚Ä¢ Brief intro/R project or problem: We'll take turns talking about an R project we're working on, a data/data-science problem, or something we want to learn, etc.

‚Ä¢ Next, anyone can share some code they've been working on and want help with / want feedback on. Make sure to have this ready before the meeting.

‚Ä¢ Before arriving, use the pdxrlang/aggregate GitHub repository to discuss ideas for things to work on at aggregate - https://github.com/pdxrlang/aggregate/issues

Please note that this event, like all PDX R events, adheres to the PDX R Code of Conduct: https://pdxrlang.com/code-of-conduct.html We are dedicated to a safe learning environment to all.

If you have any trouble message Brittany Barker in in the Meetup app, or on Twitter at @pdxrlang

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by R-Ladies Tunis: Introduction to Ensembl REST API - PART1  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Register by: Friday, June 4,[masked]:00 PM
In order to attend the event, please fill out this form üëâ
https://tinyurl.com/judj2az8

We are delighted to get back to the R4Bioinfo series that we've launched in September 2020. We will be organizing a series of two workshops about Introduction to Ensembl REST API.

Date/Time: Friday, June 4th, 2021 from 6 PM to 8:15 PM (GMT+1)
Place: ZOOM

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainers: Dr. Aleena Mushtaq and Dr. Michal Szpak

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Aleena Mushtaq:
Aleena‚Äôs background is in Biomedical and Molecular sciences. She completed her PhD in 2020 at the University of East Anglia, UK. For her doctorate she studied the dynamic relationship of host and microbiota in the gut-liver axis in response to Western diets. She joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2021 and delivers training on Ensembl resources.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Michal Szpak:
Michal took a degree in biology at the University of Warsaw, where he
studied ancient DNA. He subsequently moved to bioinformatics and
explored human genetic variation across different ethnicities in his
master‚Äôs degree research at the Center for Public Health Genomics,
university of Virginia. He joined the human evolution team at the
Wellcome Sanger Institute in 2012 and received his PhD in human
population genetics from University of Cambridge. His doctoral and
postdoctoral work at the Sanger focused on positive selection and
genetic adaptations in humans. He joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2019 and continues to deliver Ensembl training worldwide.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:
This workshop will be divided into two parts. During these two parts you'll learn about:
- Introduction to REST API
- Making requests with R
- Find an endpoint which you can use to lookup information about a gene using its symbol
- Create a URL to find information about a gene
- Expand your results to include information about transcripts
- Convert a fromJSON module used to pull out the data to a dataframe
- Get a sequence in FASTA
- Gene trees and homologues in various formats
- Alignments
- Get all variants that are associated with a phenotype and print the needed information about these variants
- Linking endpoints together
- Using POST to run a query with multiple inputs at once

By the end of this series, you will be able to make requests with R through Ensembl REST API.

We will send you the ZOOM link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by Brighton R: June Meetup  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

At the next Brighton R meetup, we will be joined by two fantastic speakers, and we‚Äôre excited to reveal that our first speaker is Tobias Stalder

'ggameboy'. Or what else we can do with ggplot2

We are pleased to welcome Tobias Stalder, Project Associate R&D at Grolimund+Partner AG, to talk at the next Brighton R meetup.

Tobias will be sharing how he built a cool data visualisation package using ggplot2 that allows you to create custom coloured Gameboy pictures!

The gameboy_plot() function allows you to change the colours of every aspect of a Gameboy wireframe, including the ability to add custom screen text messages.

So, if you‚Äôre interested in learning about some fun data visualisation things you can get up to with your data in ggplot2, then this is a talk not to be missed!

Following the presentation, you will have an opportunity to ask questions about the project and chat with others from the local Brighton R community.

ggplot2 is part of the tidyverse ecosystem of R packages, which allows you to assign variables to your data and then map onto aesthetics. You can checkout Tobias‚Äôs Github here, which includes a repository about the ggameboy project.

More speakers to be announced soon!

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by R Lille: Reproducible Computation at Scale in R with {targets}  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Original Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/R-Lille/events/277902715/

[Abstract]
The {targets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/targets/) R package enhances the reproducibility, scale, and maintainability of data science projects in computationally intense fields such as machine learning, Bayesian data analysis, and statistical genomics. {targets} resolves the dependency structure of the analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and manages data storage. {stantargets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/stantargets/) and similar packages extend {targets} to simplify pipeline construction for specialized use cases such as the validation of Bayesian models.

[Bio]
Will Landau (https://wlandau.github.io/) works at Eli Lilly and Company (https://www.lilly.com/) where he develops methods and tools for clinical statisticians, and he is the creator and maintainer of the targets and drake R packages. Will earned his PhD in Statistics at Iowa State University in 2016, where his dissertation research applied Bayesian methods, hierarchical models, and GPU computing to the analysis of RNA-seq data.

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: R-Ladies Bari: Modelli predittivi per la crescita profittevole: il caso Bene Assicurazioni  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
Bene Assicurazioni √® una realt√† in crescita dalla struttura agile, con molteplici partnership e un modello di business in multi-canalit√†. La Compagnia ha completato la digitalizzazione dei processi e crede nel continuo aggiornamento delle tecnologie adottate.

Il team BI&A √® un gruppo in crescita e con una posizione centrale nella compagnia; √® un gruppo giovane, dinamico che si occupa di:

- diffusione della ‚Äúcultura dei numeri‚Äù all‚Äôinterno della Compagnia
- governo integrato della reportistica, degli indicatori di performance e di marginalit√† tecnica
- analisi predittive, tecniche e attuariali per ottimizzare il pricing competitivo, la retention e lo sviluppo di nuovi prodotti

Dato il piano di crescita della compagnia, molto ambizioso nel breve-medio termine e da effettuarsi senza intaccare la marginalit√†, abbiamo studiato con diversi modelli predittivi come modificare il prodotto e il pricing per ottimizzare le nostra crescita, ottenendo infine risultati in linea con le aspettative (Machine Learning works!).

In questo workshop presentiamo il problema ed entriamo nei dettagli di alcuni dei modelli, dei test effettuati e del codice utilizzato per raggiungere il nostro obiettivo.

AGENDA

- Chi siamo ‚Äì Bene Assicurazioni e il Team BI&A
- Perch√© abbiamo utilizzato modelli predittivi per stimare la conversion e che risultati abbiamo ottenuto
- Descrizione dei principali algoritmi utilizzati per il modello di conversion e che criteri abbiamo utilizzato per la selezione
- Walk-through di un codice di esempio

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Text Preprocessing in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Continuing virtually, this month we have a talk about text preprocessing.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

Outside the meetups we have two events planned:

The 2021 R Conference in NY, September 8-10 as both in-person and virtual: https://rstats.ai/nyr/
The Bayes and Stan workshop, July 14-16, fully virtual: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/landeranalytics/505284

About the Talk:
Text constitutes an ever-growing part of the data available to us today. However, it is a non-trivial task to transform text, represented as long strings of characters, into numbers that we can use in our statistical and machine learning models. This talk will focus on the {textrecipes} package and its recent advancements in the realm of text preprocessing.

About Emil:
Emil Hvitfeldt is a clinical data analyst working in healthcare, and an adjunct professor at American University teaching statistical machine learning with tidymodels. He is also an open-source R developer and author of the {textrecipes} package.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EDT and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

A new workshop about Using blogdown & Hugo Ap√©ro to create your personal website.

Date/Time: Wednesday, May 26th, 2021 from 7 PM to 9 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Dr. Alison Hill

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Alison Hill :
Alison Hill is a data scientist, behavioral scientist, and an award-winning educator. Currently, Dr. Hill works to make data science communication easier and more delightful using RStudio‚Äôs open-source toolchain. Previously, Alison was an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Oregon Health & Science University. Her research focused on health-related applications of Natural Language Processing-based methods, and was funded by the National Institutes of Health, the Oregon Clinical and Translational Research Institute, and Autism Speaks. She has written numerous scientific publications on autism and neurodevelopmental disorders and has presented research at over 25 international conferences. Alison has also taught statistics and data science for over 10 years; most recently, she has led advanced workshops on data science communication and machine learning at rstudio::conf, R / Medicine, and R in Pharma. She is also an international keynote speaker (https://alison.rbind.io/talks), co-developer of the palmerpenguins (https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/), distill (https://rstudio.github.io/distill/), and blogdown (https://pkgs.rstudio.com/blogdown) R packages, and co-author of the book blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown (https://bookdown.org/yihui/blogdown/).

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:
‚ÄúYou should have a website!‚Äù You may have heard this one before, or even said it yourself. In this workshop, you‚Äôll learn how to build and customize a website from the comfort of the RStudio IDE with R Markdown. We'll use the blogdown package and the Hugo Ap√©ro theme to build and deploy a personal website. We‚Äôll cover basic website care and feeding like using R Markdown to create content, how to use GitHub for version control and Netlify for publishing, and how to use the latest upgrades to the blogdown R package to keep your site up and running.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Prerequisites

You'll get the most out of this workshop if you do the pre-work ahead of time. Please follow the instructions here: https://iyo-rstudio-global.netlify.app/collection/prework/.

title: Vienna<-R: R-Ladies Tunis / ViennaR: [R4Bioinfo] WS "Intro to Ensembl REST API" - Part 1  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
We'd like to share another R4Bioinfo series event by R-Ladies Tunis - definitely an event to look fwd to for those of you who are involved in R (or stats) for Bioinformatics.
This is part one of a series of two workshops about
"Introduction to Ensembl REST API".

Date/Time: Friday, June 4th, 2021 from 6 PM to 8:15 PM (GMT+1)
SO SHOULD BE 7 pm VIENNA TIME ...
Place: ZOOM

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainers: Dr. Aleena Mushtaq and Dr. Michal Szpak

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Aleena Mushtaq:
Aleena‚Äôs background is in Biomedical and Molecular sciences. She completed her PhD in 2020 at the University of East Anglia, UK. For her doctorate she studied the dynamic relationship of host and microbiota in the gut-liver axis in response to Western diets. She joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2021 and delivers training on Ensembl resources.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Michal Szpak:
Michal took a degree in biology at the University of Warsaw, where he
studied ancient DNA. He subsequently moved to bioinformatics and
explored human genetic variation across different ethnicities in his
master‚Äôs degree research at the Center for Public Health Genomics,
university of Virginia. He joined the human evolution team at the
Wellcome Sanger Institute in 2012 and received his PhD in human
population genetics from University of Cambridge. His doctoral and
postdoctoral work at the Sanger focused on positive selection and
genetic adaptations in humans. He joined EMBL-EBI as an Ensembl Outreach Officer in 2019 and continues to deliver Ensembl training worldwide.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:
This workshop will be divided into two parts. During these two parts you'll learn about:
- Introduction to REST API
- Making requests with R
- Find an endpoint which you can use to lookup information about a gene using its symbol
- Create a URL to find information about a gene
- Expand your results to include information about transcripts
- Convert a fromJSON module used to pull out the data to a dataframe
- Get a sequence in FASTA
- Gene trees and homologues in various formats
- Alignments
- Get all variants that are associated with a phenotype and print the needed information about these variants
- Linking endpoints together
- Using POST to run a query with multiple inputs at once

By the end of this series, you will be able to make requests with R through Ensembl REST API.

In order to attend the event, please fill out this form

title: Vienna<-R: Brighton R / ViennaR - June Meetup": {ggameboy}, Proj. Mgmnt Dashboard BPs  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
On rather short notice some info regarding the next Brighton R meetup.
Two fantastic speakers ...

First "Tobias Stalder":

'ggameboy'. Or what else we can do with ggplot2

We are pleased to welcome Tobias Stalder, Project Associate R&D at Grolimund+Partner AG, to talk at the next Brighton R meetup.

Tobias will be sharing how he built a cool data visualisation package using ggplot2 that allows you to create custom coloured Gameboy pictures!

The gameboy_plot() function allows you to change the colours of every aspect of a Gameboy wireframe, including the ability to add custom screen text messages.

So, if you‚Äôre interested in learning about some fun data visualisation things you can get up to with your data in ggplot2, then this is a talk not to be missed!

ggplot2 is part of the tidyverse ecosystem of R packages, which allows you to assign variables to your data and then map onto aesthetics. You can checkout Tobias‚Äôs Github here, which includes a repository about the ggameboy project.

Following Tobias, "Lauri Huhta":
sharing 'Best practices on creating project management dashboards' where he'll talk through the challenges he encountered with his own analytics dashboard. As part of his talk, Lauri will be demonstrating his project using R, Shiny, Jira and a bit of Python!

Following both presentations, you will have an opportunity to ask questions and chat with others from the local Brighton R community.

title: Vienna<-R: [R Lille] / ViennaR: Reproducible Computation at Scale with {targets}  [Virtual] , Austria, Europe
description:
Original Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/R-Lille/events/277902715/

[Abstract]
The {targets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/targets/) R package enhances the reproducibility, scale, and maintainability of data science projects in computationally intense fields such as machine learning, Bayesian data analysis, and statistical genomics. {targets} resolves the dependency structure of the analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and manages data storage. {stantargets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/stantargets/) and similar packages extend {targets} to simplify pipeline construction for specialized use cases such as the validation of Bayesian models.

[Bio]
Will Landau (https://wlandau.github.io/) works at Eli Lilly and Company (https://www.lilly.com/) where he develops methods and tools for clinical statisticians, and he is the creator and maintainer of the targets and drake R packages. Will earned his PhD in Statistics at Iowa State University in 2016, where his dissertation research applied Bayesian methods, hierarchical models, and GPU computing to the analysis of RNA-seq data.

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: Campus useR Group Frankfurt: June meeting: What's new in R 4.1.0?  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
On May 18, a minor update to R 4.1.0 releases: https://developer.r-project.org/

For our June meeting, let's talk about the update: Did you install the new version? Did it break your code? Looking at the changelog, what catches our eye? Can we recreate some of the bugs that the update fixes?

While the update shouldn't change much in our everyday workflows, this is an opportunity to take a more in-depth look at mechanics that we don't usually encounter using R, get more familiar with the contributors' vocabulary and maybe even discover useful functionalities.

As always, everyone is welcome to join the conversation, ask questions and share their ideas and experiences, no matter their background or skill level.

title: R-Ladies Boulder: RLadies Boulder Meetup #15: From csv to slippy map - intro to spatial data in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's virtual R Ladies Meetup! This month, Anna Spiers will be giving us an introduction to spatial data and map-making in R!

From Anna: Working with spatial data can feel as finicky as caring for your favorite houseplant - your attempts to help are rejected despite following instructions, and you look longingly at friends' and colleagues' masterpieces (i.e., maps/plants). This talk will introduce spatial data broadly, and cover some of the basic workflows and troubleshooting steps in R. Specifically, we will work with vector data, focus on the `sp` and `sf` libraries, and produce an interactive map in R. Example data and code will be provided.

We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and learn some new techniques to apply in your work!

We hope you'll also join our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7.

title: R-Ladies Philly: Panel Discussion: What Are Hiring Managers Looking For in Candidates?  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
DataPhilly, RLadiesPhilly, and the DataLab meetup groups jointly present a panel discussion with hiring managers in the fields of Data Science and Data Engineering!!

The job market for data related jobs is hot. But, job seekers usually find disparity between what recruiters say to what hiring managers really want. We hope to close this disconnect through this discussion and to help candidates better prepare for careers in data engineering or data science and to also help employers find better candidates.

Whether you are looking for a new job in data or are simply interested in what the hiring process looks like, come and ask questions to our panel of eight hiring managers. Stick around after the Q&A and meet these managers face-to-face.

Event Schedule:
1. Meeting opens at 5:45pm
2. Introductions (Starts at 6pm)
3. Panel Q&A (75 minutes)
Moderated discussion on hiring practices and expected skills and experience.
4. Meet the Hiring Managers (30 minutes)
Each hiring manager will have a separate room to meet interested candidates.

Panelists:
Oodaye Shukla - Chief Data Analytics Officer, Eversana
Jason Rodriguez - Data Science Manager, GoPuff
Ryan Harrington - Lead Data Scientist, CompassRed
Johanna-Laina Fischer - Senior Data Scientist, Comcast EBI
Anjali Bansal - Advanced Analytics Lead, Slalom
Dave O‚Äô Toole - Vice President of Analytics, Consumer Behavior, and BI, Revzilla (Comoto Holdings)
Robert Cheetham - CEO, Azavea
Steve Ross - Sr. Manager Security Data Engineering, Elastic

You must download and install Zoom if you have not done it already. Once you have installed Zoom, click on the event link provided in your email to join the meeting.

DON'T FORGET TO ADD YOUR QUESTION TO THE PANEL AFTER YOU RSVP!

title: R-Ladies Philly: R-Ladies Lightning Talks: How You Use R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join us in June for an evening of short and insightful talks related to using R. Topics will highlight the breadth of use cases our members solve using R and the packages they love. Stay tuned as we update the list of topics and speakers!

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:10 - Join online
6:10 - 6:20 - Welcome and announcement
6:20 - 7:20 - Talk part 1
7:20 - 7:25 - Short break
7:25 - 8:00 - Talk part 2

Speakers and talk titles:

* Shannon Pileggi - Leveraging the R community for the job interview

Shannon Pileggi (@PipingHotData) is an enthusiastic statistical collaborator and educator with experience partnering on data analysis in corporate, tech, and government settings. Shannon is currently a Senior Statistician at Adelphi Research in Doylestown, PA working in pharmaceutical market research. Shannon‚Äôs day-to-day in R include: fine-tuning ggplots to convey analysis results, contributing to an internal package to automate routine analyses/tasks, streamlining work-flows for repetitive analyses, and developing shiny aps.

* Alice Walsh - Data nightmares: True stories for scary data

Alice Walsh (@sciencealice), Ph.D. is a computational biologist who studies diseases at the molecular level. She is also an organizer of R-Ladies Philly and enjoys data cleaning, generating hypotheses from complex data, and mentoring others.

* Zhenya Cherkas - Rshiny : connecting the silos

Zhenya Cherkas is an Associate Director at Johnson & Johnson Global Medical Safety. Using R for over 15 years, she always worked on the better access and use of multiple disconnected data sources for better data science in less time. She holds PhD in Statistics, MS and BS in Mathematics and BS in Applied Mathematics and Computer Science.

* Jake Riley - Headliner: a new package for dynamic insights

Jake Riley is a data analyst at CHOP and the author of several R packages to improve the workflow of data analysis. His new R package, [headliner], allows users to generate dynamic, informative titles for charts and reports. Read more here https://rjake.github.io/headliner/"

* June Choe - Using icon fonts for data viz

June Choe (@yjunechoe) is a PhD student in Linguistics at the University of Pennsylvania, where he studies the mechanisms of human language acquisition and processing. He enjoys blogging about R and reading about data visualization in his free time.

* Madhavi Ratnagiri - Identification of pulmonary dysfunction using machine learning

Madhavi Ratnagiri is a research associate at the University of Delaware, with a PhD in Electrical Engineering and a Masters in Biomedical Engineering. Over the years she has worked with various types of data including speech, image and time sequence. She programs in C++, matlab, perl, R and most recently python.

title: R-Ladies Brisbane: Introduction to using Docker for reproducibility in R  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
*What are we going to learn:
Docker is a platform for creating ‚Äúcontainers‚Äù on your system. You can think of them like a mini system on your computer. They are completely self-contained, isolated environments on your system. These containers include their own operating system, application software, scripts, data, etc. Containers are useful for a lot of things, but here I‚Äôll focus on a quick introduction to using Docker for reproducibility in R. I will demonstrate on how to set-up Docker, run R on a Docker container and few other use cases.

*Who is going to present:
Malindrie is a PhD candidate at the Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology, The University of Queensland. She works on developing bioinformatics methods for the analysis of large-scale single-cell data using advanced statistical modelling and uses modern statistics tools to understand human disease. Malindrie completed her Bachelor of Science (Honours) degree in Statistics in 2016.

* When are we meeting?
The talk will start at 5:00 pm for approximately 45 mins and 15 min Q&A. After that we invite you to stay for in-person and/or virtual catch up.

description:
Dragi svi,
jos jedna super radionica sjajne Alison Hill je zakazana za 26. maj i organizuju je divne R-Ladies Tunis. Svi detalji su ovde:

We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new workshop about Using blogdown & Hugo Ap√©ro to create your personal website.

Date/Time: Wednesday, May 26th, 2021 from 7 PM to 9 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Invited trainer: Dr. Alison Hill

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About Dr. Alison Hill :
Alison Hill is a data scientist, behavioral scientist, and an award-winning educator. Currently, Dr. Hill works to make data science communication easier and more delightful using RStudio‚Äôs open-source toolchain. Previously, Alison was an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Oregon Health & Science University. Her research focused on health-related applications of Natural Language Processing-based methods, and was funded by the National Institutes of Health, the Oregon Clinical and Translational Research Institute, and Autism Speaks. She has written numerous scientific publications on autism and neurodevelopmental disorders and has presented research at over 25 international conferences. Alison has also taught statistics and data science for over 10 years; most recently, she has led advanced workshops on data science communication and machine learning at rstudio::conf, R / Medicine, and R in Pharma. She is also an international keynote speaker (https://alison.rbind.io/talks), co-developer of the palmerpenguins (https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/), distill (https://rstudio.github.io/distill/), and blogdown (https://pkgs.rstudio.com/blogdown) R packages, and co-author of the book blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown (https://bookdown.org/yihui/blogdown/).

‚ñ∂Ô∏è About the workshop:
‚ÄúYou should have a website!‚Äù You may have heard this one before, or even said it yourself. In this workshop, you‚Äôll learn how to build and customize a website from the comfort of the RStudio IDE with R Markdown. We'll use the blogdown package and the Hugo Ap√©ro theme to build and deploy a personal website. We‚Äôll cover basic website care and feeding like using R Markdown to create content, how to use GitHub for version control and Netlify for publishing, and how to use the latest upgrades to the blogdown R package to keep your site up and running.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Prerequisites

You'll get the most out of this workshop if you do the pre-work ahead of time. Please follow the instructions here: https://iyo-rstudio-global.netlify.app/collection/prework/.

In order to attend the event, please fill out this form üëâ https://tinyurl.com/dre27d3k

We will send you the zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: R-Ladies Irvine: Social Vulnerability and COVID-19 Prevalence & Predicting Benzodiazepines Use  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, May 18, 6:30-8:00 pm (Pacific)
6:30 - Welcome and Networking
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - Social vulnerability and COVID-19 prevalence in California
7:25 - Q&A
7:30 - Predicting Benzodiazepines Use
7:55 - Q&A
8:00 - Meeting Adjourned

# Social Vulnerability and COVID-19 Prevalence in California
Speakers: Tiffany Feng, Eustina Kim, Diana Pham, Kienna Qin
Seniors, Department of Statistics, UCLA

Bio: Tiffany Feng, UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Digital Humanities minor; Eustina Kim: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Digital Humanities minor; Diana Pham: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Global Health minor; Kienna Qin: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major

Abstract:
The goal of this project was to determine if there is a relationship between social vulnerability and COVID-19 case prevalence rates across counties in California. Social vulnerability is defined as the resilience of communities when dealing with external stresses on health, such as age, housing, race/ethnicity, and more. For analysis, we used multiple linear regression to determine which social vulnerability variables are most directly related with hospital capacity in each county in California, using average bed utilization rate as our measure of hospital capacity. The significant predictors from our model were: the proportion of the county‚Äôs population under 17, the percentage of individuals reporting severe housing situations, the proportion of the county's population that are Black, the percentage of single parent households, and the percentage of households with more people than rooms. We then developed a county-level social vulnerability index (SVI) and concluded that there was a relationship between the SVI and COVID-19 case prevalence per county after mapping both of them using Tableau. Our findings suggest that more socially vulnerable counties are less equipped to handle impacts of COVID-19 and more resources should be allocated to them to establish equitable health outcomes. This project was originally created in May 2020, with updates to COVID case rates in December 2020.

# Predicting Benzodiazepines Use
Speakers: Tiffany Feng, Eustina Kim, Diana Pham, Kienna Qin
Seniors, Department of Statistics, UCLA

Bio: Tiffany Feng, UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Digital Humanities minor; Eustina Kim: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Digital Humanities minor; Diana Pham: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major and Global Health minor; Kienna Qin: UCLA Class of 2021, Statistics Major

Abstract: This project explores which characteristics among students, health care professionals, and veterans determined the use of benzodiazepines (BZDs) in a sample of participants in the United States during 2018. BZDs are a type of drug that produces sedation and lowers anxiety levels. They are the most commonly prescribed medication in the U.S., and, unfortunately, are frequently abused and taken with other drugs. We used multinomial logistic regression and various data visualizations to determine that having a history of drug use, mental illness, and prescriptions for opioids for treating pain are important in predicting the use of BZD for all three occupations in our sample. The largest impacts for each occupation were a history of drug use for students, mental illness and opioid prescriptions for pain for veterans, and there were similar influences for each category for health professionals. Although our data was not a representative sample, this could still demonstrate the importance of investigating the unique differences in determining BZD use for each occupation, which could lead into interventions such as targeted programs to reduce BZD misuse in each occupation. Hopefully with these insights, we can make a positive impact on the lives of those affected by the misuse of BZDs in the United States.

# Meeting Materials
All meeting materials will be sent to registered attendees after the event.

title: R-Ladies Vienna: ggplot2 workshop with Ursula Laa, Austria, Europe
description:
We are happy to announce that for the May 2021 Meetup our co-organiser Ursula Laa will offer a tutorial into data visualisation with the ggplot2 R package.

Starting from the underlying principles of tidy data and the grammar of graphics, Ursula will introduce the basic ingredients (aesthetics and geoms) and show how to build a ggplot layer-by-layer. We will see together how we can quickly generate very different graphs with small changes in a standard interface, making it easy to better explore data.

Ursula is a researcher in the Statistics Institute of the University of Natural Resources and Life Sciences (BOKU) in Vienna and holds PhD in theoretical particle physics. She focuses in her research on new methods and applications in data science with emphasis on interdisciplinary work, for example connecting her background in physics and her interest in statistical data visualisation.

See you soon online!
Your R-Ladies Vienna Organizing Team

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: From messy data to beautiful plot: Guided TidyTuesday  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Know the basics of data wrangling but want some hands-on practice? Want to learn ggplot tips and tricks to make your plots eye-catching? Seen cool visualizations on Twitter but find it hard to go from messy dataset to beautiful visualization?

In this monthly meetup, we‚Äôll go through a Tidy Tuesday dataset together step-by-step, walking you through the entire process from coming up with an interesting question to asnwer, getting the data in the right format and finally, creating a cool visualization!

You may have heard of Tidy Tuesday -- a weekly initiative by R for Data Science which provides a new dataset every week for the community to practice wrangling and visualizing. It has a huge Twitter community and is one of the best ways to practice and develop tidyverse skills, whether you‚Äôre still reviewing the basics or have quite the repertoire. This series has something for everyone and is especially designed to be beginner friendly!

It's important to us to ensure that Guided Tidy Tuesday is a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. Studies have shown that letting gender minorities speak first promotes a welcoming and supportive atmosphere for underrepresented groups. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments / questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: AthensR: Reproducible Computation at Scale in R with {targets} [R Lille]  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
The {targets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/targets/) R package enhances the reproducibility, scale, and maintainability of data science projects in computationally intense fields such as machine learning, Bayesian data analysis, and statistical genomics. {targets} resolves the dependency structure of the analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and manages data storage. {stantargets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/stantargets/) and similar packages extend {targets} to simplify pipeline construction for specialized use cases such as the validation of Bayesian models.

[Bio]
Will Landau (https://wlandau.github.io/) works at Eli Lilly and Company (https://www.lilly.com/) where he develops methods and tools for clinical statisticians, and he is the creator and maintainer of the targets and drake R packages. Will earned his PhD in Statistics at Iowa State University in 2016, where his dissertation research applied Bayesian methods, hierarchical models, and GPU computing to the analysis of RNA-seq data.

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: R-Ladies Madrid: Empezando con clusterizaci√≥n   [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
En esta sesi√≥n comenzaremos a explorar c√≥mo de potentes son los m√©todos de clusterizaci√≥n para solucionar m√∫ltiples problemas y lo haremos a trav√©s de varios ejemplos.

Lo aprenderemos de la mano de Elena Rivas Ruzafa (https://www.linkedin.com/in/elena-rivas-ruzafa/) , Head of Engineering - Digital Products que durante la sesi√≥n nos guiar√° y aprenderemos mediante ejemplos.

Dentro del machine learning, la clusterizaci√≥n se enmarca dentro del aprendizaje no supervisado, es decir, esos algoritmos para los que solo disponemos de un conjunto de datos de entrada que no est√°n etiquetados y sobre los que obtendremos informaci√≥n sin conocer de antemano cu√°l ser√° la respuesta correcta. Esta situaci√≥n se da muy a menudo y provocar√° que la forma en la que hemos de testear los resultados sea muy particular. Tambi√©n veremos que la creaci√≥n de visualizaciones de datos y la generaci√≥n de gr√°ficos, se convertir√° en una parte esencial de la exploraci√≥n de dichos resultados.

Lo que obtendremos tras el proceso de clusterizaci√≥on ser√° una segmentaci√≥n de los datos en grupos similares que ser√°n lo que conocemos como ‚Äúcl√∫steres‚Äù. Aunque es un problema de clasificaci√≥n no debemos confundir clusterizaci√≥n con clasificaci√≥n. Ambos son m√©todos de identificaci√≥n de patrones, pero mientras el primero pertenece al aprendizaje no supervisado, el segundo, m√°s conocido, pertenece al aprendizaje supervisado. Tambi√©n trataremos de explicar estas diferencias.

Adem√°s de resolver algunos casos pr√°cticos durante la sesi√≥n, veremos c√≥mo estos m√©todos pueden solucionar diferentes problemas en m√∫ltiples √°mbitos (en medicina para el diagn√≥stico de enfermedades, en redes sociales para encontrar grupos de comportamiento similares, en finanzas para generar estrategias dirigidas a los diferentes grupos de clientes...)

Todo esto lo haremos en el entorno de programaci√≥n R en el que existen m√∫ltiples paquetes que implementan algoritmos de clustering y funciones para visualizar sus resultados. Durante la sesi√≥n trabajaremos con algunos de los m√°s interesantes.

Estas son las librer√≠as que usaremos, para que vay√°is instal√°ndolas. Las dos √∫ltimas son las espec√≠ficas de clustering:

library(tidyverse)
library(gridExtra)
library(dplyr)
library(reshape2)
library(ggmap)
library(factoextra) # clustering algorithms & visualization
library(cluster) # clustering algorithms

Aqu√≠ est√°n los materiales! https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_madrid/blob/master/README.md#[masked]---taller-online

title: R-Ladies Barcelona: Taller: "Introducci√≥n a targets"  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
¬°Bienvenidas al meetup virtual de mayo! En esta ocasi√≥n tenemos preparado un taller:

"Introducci√≥n a targets", por Irene Cruz (@irene_cruzgomez)

*Recordad que para acceder a la charla necesitar√©is una contrase√±a que os enviaremos 1 hora antes del evento.

A continuaci√≥n os dejamos la descripci√≥n del taller. ¬°Nos vemos pronto!

-------------------------------------

Descripci√≥n del taller:

En este taller se hace una presentaci√≥n de las estrategias de canalizaci√≥n de flujos de trabajo (workflow pipelines) usando el paquete targets.

En la primera parte del taller se explica c√≥mo la estructuraci√≥n del c√≥digo en pipelines es el mejor modo de garantizar la reproducibilidad de nuestros resultados y de aliviar la carga mental que supone la organizaci√≥n de un proyecto complejo con diversas piezas interdependientes. Esta metodolog√≠a de trabajo nos va a permitir reproducir el c√≥digo sin repetir los pasos ya completados, ejecutar c√°lculos con computaci√≥n paralela cuando sea necesario, y guardar un registro ordenado de los distintos objetos creados.

En la segunda parte del taller se realizar√° un ejemplo guiado del uso de targets y se presentar√°n algunos tips para sacarle el m√°ximo partido, como usar branching, introducir revisiones autom√°ticas de resultados, o estrategias para depurar c√≥digo.

Requisitos: el taller supone cierta familiaridad previa con el c√≥digo de R y con la definici√≥n de funciones.

-------------------------------------

Sobre Irene Cruz:

Hola! Me llamo Irene Cruz, soy doctora en Sociolog√≠a por la UAB. Trabajo como metod√≥loga en el IERMB y como profesora asociada de m√©todos y t√©cnicas de investigaci√≥n en la UAB.

title: R-Ladies Santa Barbara: A Gentle Introduction to Parallel Processing in R with Danielle Ferraro  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
PLEASE NOTE: This event has been rescheduled for Wednesday, May 26th from 5:30-7:00pm PT.

Ready to learn how to write faster code? In this workshop, Danielle will provide an overview on parallel processing - that is, how to take advantage of your computer‚Äôs multicore processor to complete large tasks more quickly. title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Exploring Our Universe Through Sight & Sound (or Touch!)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Information of cosmic objects doesn't have to be just a two-dimensional snap shot. We can transform these data to be able to listen, feel, or (virtually) move through the cosmos through virtual reality and even holograms. Such data taken from telescopes in space ‚Äì often in light invisible to the human eye ‚Äì can be translated into many different forms to help provide access to some of space‚Äôs most interesting and mysterious objects. Dr. Kimberly Arcand, from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory, will take you to the debris from an exploded star through sound, walk you through the core of our Milky Way virtually, discuss feeling vibrations of a stellar nursery, and help you experience our universe anew.

For information about our speaker, Kimberly Arcand, please go to https://www.kimarcand.com/about.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Books In Bars - Lessons from Plants  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Spend Friday night discussing Lessons from Plants (https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/lessons-from-plants-beronda-l-montgomery/1137725290).

An exploration of how plant behavior and adaptation offer valuable insights for human thriving.

We know that plants are important. They maintain the atmosphere by absorbing carbon dioxide and producing oxygen. They nourish other living organisms and supply psychological benefits to humans as well, improving our moods and beautifying the landscape around us. But plants don‚Äôt just passively provide. They also take action.

Beronda L. Montgomery explores the vigorous, creative lives of organisms often treated as static and predictable. In fact, plants are masters of adaptation. They ‚Äúknow‚Äù what and who they are, and they use this knowledge to make a way in the world. Plants experience a kind of sensation that does not require eyes or ears. They distinguish kin, friend, and foe, and they are able to respond to ecological competition despite lacking the capacity of fight-or-flight. Plants are even capable of transformative behaviors that allow them to maximize their chances of survival in a dynamic and sometimes unfriendly environment.

Lessons from Plants enters into the depth of botanic experience and shows how we might improve human society by better appreciating not just what plants give us but also how they achieve their own purposes. What would it mean to learn from these organisms, to become more aware of our environments and to adapt to our own worlds by calling on perception and awareness? Montgomery‚Äôs meditative study puts before us a question with the power to reframe the way we live: What would a plant do?

Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the capabilities to run R **and** RStudio. See information above about how to install R **and** RStudio.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

description:
This R-Ladies Tbilisi meetup is happy to welcome Elisa Schneider (see bio below)! During this workshop we will introduce the concept of version control using Git, RStudio and GitHub. We will learn the basic Git commands and how to use them directly from R-Studio. Elisa Schneider will show how to link your R-Projects with GitHub to create online repositories to share your work and how it can be used for collaboration. At the end she will do a short demo on uploading a small WebPage to Github such as the one from R-Ladies Seattle https://github.com/rladies-seattle/rladies-seattle-organizing. If we have enough time she will introduce other possibilities such as GitHub Webpages like this one: https://kyla-mcconnell.github.io/website/index.html.

If you have some time to prepare before the Meetup, Elisa recommends to:
¬∑ create a GitHub account (if you do not have one yet) on https://github.com/
¬∑ download and install Git from https://git-scm.com/

For the last part of the meetup some very basic knowledge of markdown/Rmarkdown is recommended, but not mandatory, we will also go through it. If you want, you can have a look at the first 35 minutes of this video about RMarkdown: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H91WSwALx1A

Bio
Elisa Schneider comes from Argentina. She studied Biology and also got a degree on Science Education. She specialized in Remote Sensing data analysis and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). She practiced as environmental assessment consultant and also taught cartography and GIS for park rangers. Thanks to a scholarship from the German Academic Exchange Service she was able to complete a master on Environmental Modeling in 2019, at the University of Freiburg. Since then she has been working on the Forest Reaserch Institute of Baden-W√ºrttemberg, Germany evaluating forest health from remote sensing data, modeling species distribution and outbreaks of pest insects under climate change. In 2019 she joined R-Ladies Freiburg as a Co-Organizer.

title: R-Ladies Dallas: "Latent Profile Analyses using tidyLPA" with Danica Slavish  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For the June 1st edition of our R-Ladies Dallas webinar series, we are excited to welcome Dr. Danica Slavish as our guest speaker. Dr. Slavish will introduce the topic of Latent Profile Analyses using the tidyLPA framework.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Session title: Latent Profile Analyses using tidyLPA
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Abstract: Do adolescents who try alcohol before age 15 have worse health in adulthood than those who try alcohol later in life? Are there different subtypes of COVID-19 symptoms? How do these subtypes predict hospitalization risk? What types of advertisements most strongly predict if someone buys a product?

All these questions can be answered using the statistical technique, latent profile analysis (LPA). LPA is a powerful statistical tool to identify hidden clusters in your data based on a set of variables. LPA is superior to other data reduction techniques like k-means clustering in that it generates probabilities of group membership. In this talk, a brief introduction to LPA using the R package tidyLPA will be covered. Using sample data on daily sleep patterns of nurses, we will walk through an example using the current gold standard 3-step approach: 1) estimate class membership, 2) extract class probabilities, 3) examine predictors of class membership. Best practices and advantages and disadvantages of LPA will be discussed.

Bio: Dr. Danica Slavish is an Assistant Professor of Psychology at the University of North Texas. Danica‚Äôs research focuses on how sleep problems and stressful life experiences interact to predict health outcomes across time. Her research team uses a variety of statistical techniques for analyzing longitudinal data in R, including multilevel modeling, time-varying effect modeling, network analyses, and Bayesian analyses. Danica currently teaches courses in health psychology, advanced statistics, and research methods. Before joining UNT, Danica completed her Ph.D. in biobehavioral health at Penn State, where she was a National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellow. She holds an undergraduate degree in psychology from Beloit College, in Beloit, WI.

Twitter: https://twitter.com/danicaslavish

title: R-Ladies Milan: Modelli predittivi per la crescita profittevole: il caso Bene Assicurazioni  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
In questo evento siamo lieti di ospitare un workshop pratico di Bene Assicurazioni, che condivider√† con noi come stanno risolvendo le loro sfide quotidiane utilizzando R & big data.

Bene Assicurazioni √® una realt√† in crescita dalla struttura agile, con molteplici partnership e un modello di business in omni-canalit√†. La Compagnia ha completato la digitalizzazione dei processi e crede nel continuo aggiornamento delle tecnologie adottate.

Il team BI&A √® un gruppo in crescita e con una posizione centrale nella compagnia; √® un gruppo giovane, dinamico che si occupa:

Della diffusione della ‚Äúcultura dei numeri‚Äù all‚Äôinterno della Compagnia
Del governo integrato della reportistica, degli indicatori di performance e di marginalit√† tecnica
Delle analisi predittive, tecniche e attuariali per ottimizzare il pricing competitivo, la retention e lo sviluppo di nuovi prodotti
Dato il piano di crescita della compagnia, molto ambizioso nel breve-medio termine e da effettuarsi senza intaccare la marginalit√†, abbiamo studiato con diversi modelli predittivi come modificare il prodotto e il pricing per ottimizzare le nostra crescita, ottenendo infine risultati in linea con le aspettative (Machine Learning works!).

In questo workshop presentiamo il problema ed entriamo nei dettagli di alcuni dei modelli, dei test effettuati e del codice utilizzato per raggiungere il nostro obiettivo.

L'evento sar√† in Italiano e sar√† trasmesso in streaming tramite Zoom (Non √® necessario installare zoom).
Il materiale per il workshop sar√† condiviso prima dell'evento.

AGENDA
- Chi siamo ‚Äì Bene Assicurazioni e il Team BI&A
- Perch√© abbiamo utilizzato modelli predittivi per stimare la conversion e che risultati abbiamo ottenuto
- Descrizione dei principali algoritmi utilizzati per il modello di conversion e che criteri abbiamo utilizzato per la selezione
- Walk-through di un codice di esempio

Speakers:
+Alessandra Guazzi: Responsabile BI&A e Direct Product Manager;Laureata in Matematica, con un'esperienza di dottorato di ricerca, lavora in Allianz SE come Data Analyst e partecipa all'avvio di un team dedicato all'ottimizzazione dei prezzi per Allianz Australia (Direct). Dopo un'incursione in campo biomedico, lavora come manager in pricing & analytics presso Willis Towers Watson e nel gruppo Cerved.
+Alessandra Villa: Senior Pricing Expert; Laureata in Scienze Statistiche ed Economiche, lavora come attuario presso Zurich Connect per 4 anni, per poi passare a un'esperienza come Pricing Developer in AM Trust. √à in Bene Assicurazioni da 2 anni, coordinando le attivit√† di Pricing e Reportistica degli andamenti tecnici.
+Giulia Del Monaco: Data Analyst: Laureata in Biostatistica, inizia a lavorare in Bene nel 2020, dopo 2 esperienze in consulenza (Telematics e Pharma) come data analyst. Ha ottenuto il master in Big Data & Business Analytics del Sole 240re, dove ha supportato il docente con attivit√† di tutoring. Si occupa principalmente di automazione e modelli predittivi in R.
+Simone Cavenago: BI Analyst; Laureato in Scienze Statistiche ed Economiche, inizia a lavorare per Bene Assicurazioni nel 2018. Come principale responsabilit√†, segue la preparazione ed analisi dei dati e mantiene e sviluppa sulla piattaforma di Business Intelligence (bReport), tutta la reportistica direzionale e dedicata alle agenzie.

Non vedo l'ora di incontrarvi!

title: R-Ladies New York: Data Visualization: Color Palettes, Themes, and Schemes  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For our June event, R-Ladies Anna Sofia Kircher and Joyce Robbins will share short talks about using color palettes, themes, and schemes to improve data visualization in R.

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event.

Agenda (times approximate):
7-7:05 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:05-7:30: ‚Äúggplot and I‚Äù by Anna Sofia Kircher
7:30-7:55: ‚ÄúDoes your color palette match your data?‚Äù by Joyce Robbins
7:55-8:15: Questions and wrap-up

--- Talk Abstract ---

‚Äúggplot and I‚Äù
Speaker: Anna Sofia Kircher

Abstract: This talk will be about how to use ggplot themes and how to personalize them for your purposes. This is motivated by my own obsession with colors and my own experience that different plots with different audiences respond differently to different themes.

Bio: Anna Sofia Kircher is the data scientist at Lendable and works with data of various fintechs in emerging and frontier markets.

‚ÄúDoes your color palette match your data?‚Äù
Speaker: Joyce Robbins

Abstract: One of the most common graphical mistakes is choosing an inappropriate color scheme for your data. In this talk, I‚Äôll explain how sequential, diverging and qualitative color schemes are each suited to a different type of data. We‚Äôll then look at a variety of plots that could be improved with alternative color choices. My hope is that these examples will serve as conversation starters for a lively discussion on matching color to data.

Bio: Joyce Robbins (@jtrnyc) is a Lecturer in the Department of Statistics at Columbia University. She specializes in data visualization and statistical literacy.

---

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

For questions regarding accessibility, please email us at [masked].

title: R-Ladies Calgary: Getting Started in R: A Beginner's Guide  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Are you new to R? This is the workshop for you!

This workshop is for anyone who is interested in learning R, but doesn‚Äôt know where to start! With new folks joining throughout the year, we feel it is important to hold a session for our beginner level members, in order to help establish a strong foundation of skills in R. In this introductory session, we will be going over the basics: how to navigate the different file types, expressions, commands, operators, objects, loops, and MORE!

This session will be led by co-organizer, Cassidy Da Silva (she/her). Cassidy completed her Honours Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Biology with an Interdisciplinary Minor in Archaeology at McMaster University in 2019. She is now completing her master‚Äôs degree in the Hallgrimsson lab at the University of Calgary, studying the genetics underlying sex differences in human facial morphology. Her primary research interests include morphology, human anatomy, complex trait genetics, and human evolution.

title: R-Ladies Concepci√≥n: Club de lectura del libro "Data Feminism" (sesi√≥n 1)  [Virtual] , Chile, Latin America
description:
¬°Hola!

Este jueves 3 de junio nos reuniremos para nuestra primera sesi√≥n del club de lectura del libro "Data Feminism", de Catherine D'Ignazio y Lauren F. Klein. Este libro muestra una nueva forma de abordar la ciencia de datos y la √©tica de datos basada en ideas del feminismo interseccional. Se puede acceder de forma gratuita en: https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/

¬øC√≥mo funciona el club de lectura?

Divideremos la lectura del libro en seis sesiones. En cada una de ellas abordaremos un cap√≠tulo del libro. Cada sesi√≥n la liderar√° alguien de nuestra comunidad.
Esta primera sesi√≥n estar√° a cargo de Natalia Riquelme (@NatyRiquelmeS), Administradora P√∫blica, estudiante de Mag√≠ster en Estad√≠stica y Coordinadora de proyectos del Centro de Estudios de Conflicto y Cohesi√≥n Social. Durante la sesi√≥n comentaremos el cap√≠tulo 1, "The Power Chapter", en el que se se presenta el primer principio del feminismo de datos: examinar el poder.

- ¬øQu√© pasa si no leo en ingl√©s?

¬°Puedes participar igual! La persona encargada de cada sesi√≥n har√° una s√≠ntesis de los puntos m√°s importantes, as√≠ que incluso si no puedes revisar el libro, podr√°s aprender sobre este tema :)

- C√ìDIGO DE CONDUCTA

Queremos que este sea un espacio de aprendizaje amable y seguro. Al inscribirte en este evento est√°s aceptando nuestro c√≥digo de conducta: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct#spanish
El evento se realizar√° a trav√©s de la plataforma Zoom. El d√≠a del taller compartiremos la contrase√±a en los comentarios del evento.
